comments.body: this should say what direction the saw tooth is in. Presumably, it goes from 0.0 to 1.0 `count` times, with a discontinuous drop from 1.0 back to 0.0 between each iteration.
presumably where the comment below says "step" it really means "`t==threshold`" or some such.
we really should explain FlippedCurve more.
Does " a mapping of the unit interval to the unit interval" really help clarify what an easing curve is?
It explains it better than "easing curve" for people who understand math but not the term "easing curve"... I'm open to even better explanations though. :-)

Maybe we can use the definition of easing from Material Design?

> Easing is a way to adjust an animation’s rate of change. Easing allows transitioning elements to speed up and slow down, rather than moving at a constant rate.
>
> In the real world, things don’t start or stop moving instantaneously. They take time to speed up and slow down. Easing makes elements move as though influenced by natural forces like friction."

https://material.io/design/motion/speed.html#easing


Alternatives I've seen from design website:

* "An easing curve is a line that defines the acceleration pattern on a graph." [1]
* "Easing functions specify the rate of change of a parameter over time." [2]



1. https://www.invisionapp.com/blog/crafting-easing-curves/
2. https://easings.net/

the next sentence is: "Easing curves are used to adjust the rate of change of an animation over time."

I've added "allowing them to speed up and slow down, rather than moving at a constant rate."

"a line that defines the acceleration pattern on a graph" doesn't really make sense.
"specify the rate of change of a parameter over time" is what the current text says.
there's a lot of subjective adjectives here. What each person can mentally visualize this to be can be very different.
I'm not sure how to make this easier to understand? I'm also linked the bezier curve so people can see exactly what it looks like by clicking on the link?
Not sure how publicly re-usable this is if we can't describe it in an objective way. I'd just leave this privately defined in route.dart.
I can totally do this, but I guess I'm unclear on how you're measuring a description's objectivity?
These ones seem better described. Remember to add an animation movie here and in the class doc. @dnfield has this fresh in his mind so he might be able to help.
